bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 3, 1928

div1.p: Carter describes her health and her work on the bibliography of the History of Yellow Fever. She asks if her arrangement with her assistant is satisfactory to Russell.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 3, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Russell
DIVISION
////////
----------
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
May 3, 1928
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I should have earlier acknowledged your letter of April 30th.,
but have been waiting for the reprints, of which you wrote, which have
not yet arrived. I am looking forward to reading them with much in-
terest, but feel sure that it is unnecessary to assure you that, while
they may add yet another reason for pressing the work on Father's book,
nothing is could further add to my desire or efforts to do so.

I shall be glad to drop you a note once a wekek as to the pro-
gress of the work. Indeed, I have wondered before now as to whether it
would not be better for me to take a little time from the work to write
more about it. I've been so desperately anxious to finish, however,
that I've always ended by working up to my absolute limit each day and
have been too tired when I stopped to do anything else. This, both be-
fore and after I went to the Hopkins, as wellas during the last two
weeks of my stay there when I was working four hours daily, under Dr.
Thayer's supervision. Since my return from hospital, I haven't missed
a day from the work and my letter of April 28th. was not to report that
I was just resuming work, but that I had changed my base of operations
from the Westmoreland to the Library of Congress. Prior to that, I had
had
-2-
gone to the Library when necessary, but had generally worked up the re-suolts at home.

Miss Brown, of whom I wrote you, and I are making very satisfac-
tory progress on the bibliography. We began with the Section on Africa, Dr.
Frost having agreed with me that this part, being especially difficult from
a linguistic standpoint, had best be undertaken first. Miss Brown is giving
me more time than she had at first thought possible and can give me yet more
later, when she finishes some other outside work. In addition to what we did
last week we accomplished a lot together last Sunday.

In connection with Miss Brown's services I would again respectfully
request information as to whether my tentative arrangement with her, as per
my letter of April 28th., meets with your approbation. She is turning out to
be even more of a help than I anticipated.
div1.closer:
With kindest regards, I remain
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
P. S.
The reprints have just arrived.
I shall read them with much
interest.
